content: , walks through the frenzy. A postdoc hands him a printout
a pulse followed by echoes. INT.
'S OFFICE, CALTECH -- DAY
steps into the relative calm of a large, sunlit office, which overlooks a grassy stretch of Caltech's campus. His
, 30s, is on the phone, on hold. He looks up at
as he enters.
I'm on hold with the INS. (COVERS MICROPHONE)
't you think we should double check the triangulation before we CALL ANYBODY-
We have double checked it. Someone finally picks up the line.
Yes. I'm trying to reach- (pause, listens) No, I
't think you understand how serious this is. (PAUSE) Because if you did, we'd be having this conversation in person. He listens for a moment, then hangs up the phone, confused.
What did they say?
They said we should look out the window.
steps to the window and looks out

In the courtyard below, coeds are scrambling to get out of the way as a military helicopter sets down in the middle of the quad and dozens of ARMED FEDERAL AGENTS converge on his building. 3. INT. MAIN CONFERENCE ROOM,
, CALTECH -- DAY
sits, alone, on one side of a conference table. The other side is filled with GOVERNMENT MEN -- NSA mostly, some DIA. The door opens and his
steps in. Armed guards pat him down, then shove him into a seat.
Is that really necessary? One of the NSA agents leans forward.
You've been complaining for years that the government doesn't take your project seriously enough,
. (SMILES) You can't have it both ways.
motions to his
, who turns on a projector. On-screen, we see the familiar pulse and echoes.
Yesterday morning, our facility in Hanford identified this signal

a neutron star colliding with a supermassive black hole. We went through the last year's data and triangulated the source. The pulse is translated into a crude animatic of a neutron star circling into the black hole.
We know that,
. What we

't know is why, according to your numbers, this event took place right here in our own solar system. Suddenly, the image overlays the sun, the earth, and the rest of our solar system around the black hole.

It didn't. Because if it had we'd all be dead by now. On-screen, Jupiter, then the Earth and the inner planets are consumed by the black hole. Only the sun survives, pulled into orbit around its new master.
(CONT'D) Which leaves only one explanation
The signal traveled through a (MORE) 4.

(CONT'D) wormhole. A gateway to a distant corner of the universe. The black hole is on the far side. On-screen, the black hole system is removed to a distant corner, connected to ours by a tunnel through space-time. A gravity wave from the collision travels through the tunnel.
I've read your book,
. You said that wormholes are impossible.

There is nothing quite as satisfying as being proved utterly wrong. (SMILES) I said that a wormhole couldn't exist naturally. Not for more than a few billionths of a second. It would have to be... stabilized.
Stabilized by what?
pauses, unsure. His
steps in to his defense.
We
't have any way to answer that question.
(IGNORES HIM) You're not under peer review here,
. I
't care about your reputation. I need to know how that thing got there. Now.
finally speaks up.

If you're worried about an invasion, I would start drafting the articles of surrender. (SMILES) Whoever they are, if they can build a wormhole, they could erase us in the blink of an eye. Luckily, that also means we have nothing they could be interested in.
Then why is it there? 5.
I
't know. Maybe it's an invitation. A chance to commune with an advanced species. The
, embarrassed, looks down. The agent notices.
You
't agree?
(DELICATE) No. I

't think we can assume an alien intelligence built the wormhole. (CHANGES TACK) But the opportunity it represents is incredible. We could explore parts of the universe we never dreamt of reaching in our lifetimes. The agent exchanges a look with one of his colleagues, who steps out of the room.
We need to get back to work. I have a conference call with our European partners in fifteen minutes.
We severed the connections to your European partners this morning.

(INDIGNANT) You can't do that. The Europeans put up some of the funding... GOVERNMENT MAN We'll send them a check. (STANDS) Your project is now classified under the State Secrets Act. He steps out the door, leaving the men alone. The
, outraged, turns back to his boss.
They can't keep this a secret. You know that. Sooner or later... The younger man looks down, embarrassed, as he notices that tears are rolling down the older man's cheeks. 6.
I

't care about that. I've spent my whole life being afraid we would wipe ourselves out before this moment arrived. We've made so many mistakes, I wasn't sure we'd make it... The assitant realizes that the old man is weeping for joy. Relief.

(CONT'D) But this will change everything. Fifty years from now, nothing will be the same. The older man looks at the simulation on the screen of the tiny link between our galaxy and another. FADE TO BLACK EXT. CORNFIELD, CENTRAL CALIFORNIA -- DAY Corn. As far as the eye can see. SUPER TITLE

A large old diesel tour bus is parked by the side of a dirt road, smoke pouring out of its open hood. A dozen MEN in BASEBALL UNIFORMS are standing around the front of the bus. A battered PICKUP pulls up, and a MAN, 30s, gets out, leaving his two SONS in the car. This is
. He joins the ballplayers staring at the lifeless diesel engine. BALLPLAYER Seized up on us.
Long way to come by bus. I thought you guys would have a plane. BALLPLAYER We did. Ran out of parts for it. You know anything about diesels?
A little.
steps to the engine compartment. The ballplayer notices
's two boys,
, 15, and
, 10, watching them. He wanders over. 7. BALLPLAYER You think your dad's going to be able to help us out?
, a filth-encrusted kid with a black eye, smiles at the ballplayer.
My dad can fix anything. (WRY SMILE) Except maybe your fastball. The ballplayer frowns
smartass kid. After a moment under the hood,
signals to the driver, who tries the engine. It turns over once, then STARTS. BALLPLAYER Sure appreciate the help.
(SHRUGS) You
't make it, my boys won't get to see you lose. The ballplayers load up into the bus and as it pulls away, we can see the logo painted across the back of the bus for the first time

WORLD FAMOUS NEW YORK YANKEES EXT. SPACE, NEAR EARTH ORBIT Earth spins, lazily. From this height, it looks much the same as it has done for thousands of years. Suddenly, a tiny black object appears, racing toward Earth. The object SMASHES into a large satellite and races onward. Behind it, the satellite spins out of orbit in a cloud of fragments. EXT. BASEBALL STADIUM -- NIGHT An old minor league stadium. The stands are barely halfway full.
, his boys, and
's father-in-law,
, 60s, have a row to themselves behind the dugout.
offers his grandpa some popcorn.
Popcorn at a ball game is unnatural. I want a hot dog. 8.
(CONFUSED) What's a hot dog? Suddenly, play stops on the field below as the players and fans look up at the night sky
A bright blue streak is tearing across it. It's beautiful.
Is that a comet, Dad?

(shakes his head) Satellite. Big one. Probably Chinese. Everyone watches the fireworks as the satellite burns up in the upper atmosphere. After a moment, play resumes -- it's a pretty show, but everyone has seen it plenty of times before. Down on the field, the Dodgers' catcher misses an easy pop fly and the Yankees load the bases.
looks disgusted. INT.
'S TRUCK -- NIGHT
guides his truck along a potholed road. His father- in-law is riding shotgun; the boys are sleeping in the back.
Those clowns would get their asses handed to them by the ballplayers I grew up watching.
You ruin it for the boys when you talk like that.
I'm not doing my grandkids any favors by lying to them. They're growing up watching lousy baseball.
They didn't have any baseball at all when I was a kid. That shuts the old man up for now. They drive on in silence. CUT TO
9. EXT. FARMHOUSE -- MORNING The sun is gently landing on the horizon, painting the sea of corn around
's modest house gold.
walks out of his house, still eating his breakfast.
is on the porch, looking at a black clouds of smoke in the distance. The neighboring fields are BURNING.
Nelson's burning up his crops. Found some of the blight on the okra.
watches the men walking through the fields, setting fire to the crop.
I thought okra wasn't susceptible.
(SHRUGS) Better safe than sorry. (looks at him) You've got to take the boys to school.
Something wrong with your truck?
(SMILES) Parent-teacher conference day.
bends his head in dismay.
(CONT'D) Be nice to
's teacher. She's single, you know.
What does that have to do with anything?
We're supposed to be repopulating the earth. Gotta pull your weight. Besides, the boys could do with a woman in their lives. The boys run out of the house and pile into the truck.
pulls away before
can continue. EXT. ROAD -- DAY
weaves the car along a dirt road. The kids are arguing over an ancient comic book in the back seat. 10.
turns around to break it up. BANG -- one of the tires blows out in a foot-deep pothole. EXT. ROADSIDE -- DAY
examines the flattened tire. Looks at his older son.
Get the spare,
That is the spare.
All right. We'll use the patch kit. He moves to the back of the truck.
suddenly looks very glum.
I... I think the patch kit might not be there... (off his look) Because I was using it for my bike.
looks down at the dirt. Sighs.
's law.
(CONFUSED) What's that?
snorts with laughter. Turns to his dad.
The kid doesn't even know what he was named after...
shoots
a look -- enough.
(CONT'D)
's law means what can go wrong will go wrong.
, looking hurt, walks off.
turns to his son.
Find something to patch it with.
How am I supposed to do that? 11.
Figure it out. I'm not always going to be here to help you.
leaves
to catch up with his younger son, who is looking out over the river.
Is that really why I'm named
, dad?
Listen to me.
's law doesn't mean that. It means what can happen will happen. All kinds of things. Good or bad. And that's the way you want it to be.
Why?
Because if nothing ever happened to you then you wouldn't learn anything.
is staring off into the distance. He's heard something.
(CONT'D)
? Then
hears it, too. A LOW RUMBLING SOUND.

looks out over the river. Then he turns back and tackles his son to the ground. Suddenly, a MASSIVE AIRPLANE SOARS overhead, so close they can almost touch it. It bounces the truck on its suspension, then soars off over the fields behind them.
grabs
and races back to the truck. He pulls a laptop and an antenna made out of a Pringles can out of the back of the truck. He hands the laptop and antenna to
(CONT'D) Get in.
is still standing by the side of the road, wrestling with the jack.
What about the tire? INT. TRUCK -- MOMENTS LATER The truck is SMASHING through the cornfields as fast as
can push it on three good tires. 12.
is hurriedly firing up the laptop and connecting it to the directional antenna.
is straining to see through the cornstalks, scanning the horizon.
OVER THERE- To the right, the dark shape of the Russian drone appears, flying low over the fields.

jerks the wheel-- EXT. RIVER -- DAY The truck BURSTS out of the corn and SPLASHES across the river and into an old, abandoned suburban housing development in the valley below, planted over with corn. Half a mile in front of them, the Russian drone is still hugging the ground. It has impossibly long, skinny wings, like an old U-2 surveillance plane, but no cockpit. The tops of its wings are covered in black solar cells. INT. TRUCK -- DAY
is fiddling with the computer. His older brother takes the computer from him and fires up emulation software.
It's a Chinese military drone. Solar cells could power an entire farm. (TO
) Take the wheel.
hands
the Pringles can antenna.
(CONT'D) Keep it pointed right at it, OK?
nods.
takes the wheel as his dad works the laptop, trying to communicate with the huge Russian drone. The screen fills with Cyrillic characters.
(CONT'D) Faster,
. I'm losing it.
WEAVES the truck at speed through the old, curved streets of the development, past oversized suburban mansions planted over with corn. They round a corner and come face-to-face with a
harvester.
jerks the wheel to avoid it. BANG -- the truck loses a wing mirror against the flank of the combine. 13. EXT. SUBURBAN DEVELOPMENT -- DAY

guides the truck from street to street, trying to chart a straight path across the fields. The truck BOUNCES as it SMASHES through an old picket fence. Ahead, the drone is soaring, banking, pulling away. INT. TRUCK -- DAY
is still trying to hack into the drone's control circuitry as they leave the development behind and begin to climb into the foothills of the Sierras. EXT. RIDGELINE, HILLS -- DAY
guides the truck along the spine of the hills. The drone soars overhead, making for the white tips of the Sierras. INT. TRUCK -- DAY
is oblivious to the picturesque surroundings as he concentrates on the laptop.
(UNSURE) Dad?
Almost got it.
't slow down. In front of them,
and his brother watch as the drone plummets from view.
DAD.
looks up. Ahead, the trail disappears as the edge of the hills falls away -- it's a three hundred-foot drop.
locks up the brakes. EXT. RIDGELINE, HILLS -- DAY The truck skids to a halt inches from a precipitous drop.
climbs out, holding the laptop.
climbs out next to him, still pointing the Pringles can.
We lost it.
(SMILING) No we didn't. 14. Suddenly, the drone SOARS back over them.
types a couple keys and then moves his fingers across the trackpad. The huge drone banks and turns in response. As the boys watch,
sends the drone soaring high over them, banking and soaring along the tree-lined sides of the valley, light glinting from the black panels on its back. It's a beautiful sight.
crouches next to
(CONT'D) You want to give it a whirl?
looks at his dad, wide-eyed. He takes the laptop and moves his fingers gingerly across the pad. In response, the massive plane banks into a tight turn in the valley below. For a moment,
is in pure heaven, sending the drone dancing through the valley below.
(CONT'D) Set her down in the valley -- there, next to the river.

leads the plane in a figure eight and then begins guiding it into a gentle landing in the valley floor below. EXT. ABANDONED GOLF COURSE, VALLEY FLOOR -- DAY The truck limps along the overgrown fairway of a long-defunct golf course towards the massive hulk of the Russian drone,
and the boys climb down. The valley is silent save for the truck's engine WHEEZING and SPUTTERING as it cools.
runs a hand over the smooth carbon flank of the drone.
How long do you think it's been up there, Dad?
Chinese mission control went down same as us, twenty years ago. It's been up there ever since.
What was it doing flying so low?
reads the information pouring into his laptop. 15.
It was looking for something. Intercepted some kind of signal. (SHRUGS) It's been at eighty thousand feet. Sun probably cooked its brain.

runs his hand along the flank till he finds an access patch. He pulls out a crowbar and pries open the hatch. Inside, surrounded by a nest of liquid cooling tubes, is a small black module -- the drone's auto-pilot.
looks down at
, who is standing at his elbow.
What are you going to do with it?
Reprogram it. Give it something socially responsible to do like drive a combine or a tractor.
(QUIET) Couldn't we just let it go? It's not hurting anyone.
looks down at his son. Good kid.
We need all the help we can get,
. This thing has to adapt, just like the rest of us.

gently pries the control module out. EXT. COUNTY SCHOOL -- DAY It's a small school, so all the kids and parents waiting in front know exactly who's driving the pickup truck with half of a Russian spy plane hanging out of the bed as it pulls up. INT.
'S OFFICE, COUNTY SCHOOL -- DAY
is ushered into the office. The
, 40s, an efficient-looking man, shakes his hand.
Good to see you, Mr.
. This is Ms.
's teacher.
smiles at Ms.
, 30s, attractive. 16.
(CONT'D) So we've gotten
's score back. Congratulations. He's going to make an excellent farmer. The
slides a carbon copy across the desk to
, who looks taken aback.
What about college?
The University of California only accepts a few hundred students a year, Mr.
. You have to be realistic.
You're ruling out college for him now? He's only fifteen.
I'm sorry. I'm afraid
's score simply isn't high enough.
What are you, about a 36-inch waist? (BEAT) 30-inch inseam?
I'm not sure I see--
You're telling me you need two numbers to measure your own ass, but just one to measure my son's future? Ms.
stifles a laugh, then, with a look from the
, takes on the appropriate look of offense.
I understand you're a well-educated man, Mr.
. A scientist?
Engineer.
Frankly, the world doesn't need any more engineers. We didn't run out of trains or television sets or satellites. (BEAT) We ran out of food. 17.
leans back. He's not going to win this one.
(CONT'D) The world needs farmers, Mr.
. And I'm sure your son
is going to make a fine one. (SMILES BENIGNLY) We're a caretaker generation. But things are getting better. Maybe your grandchildren will be able to attend college.
looks down, swallowing his anger.
Are we done?
One more thing. Ms.
here says that
brought a book to school about the lunar landings. He slides an old textbook with a picture of a rocket on the cover across the desk to
One of my old textbooks.
liked the pictures. MS.
This is one of the old federal textbooks. We've replaced them with corrected versions.
Corrected? MS.
The new textbooks explain that the Apollo lunar missions were faked in order to bankrupt the Soviet Union.
You
't believe we went to the moon? MS.
I believe it was a brilliant piece of propaganda. The Soviets spent years trying to build rockets and other useless machines.
looks to the
for help. None is forthcoming. MS.
Yes, Mr.
. The kind of wastefulness and excess that the 20th century represented. Your children would be better off learning about this planet, rather than reading fantasies about leaving it.
is silent for a long moment.

One of those useless machines they used to make was called an MRI. If we had any of them left the doctors might have been able to find the cyst in my wife's brain before she died, rather than afterwards. And then my kids could have been raised by two parents, instead of me and their pain-in-the-ass grandfather. Ms.
's face falls, ashen.
swallows his anger. Most of it, anyway.
(CONT'D) You ever consider the best thing for the world and humanity might have been for us to part company?
gets up to leave. INT. TRUCK, COUNTY SCHOOL PARKING LOT -- DAY
climbs into the truck, trying to hold it together. He PUNCHES the wheel. The radio KEYS to life. He ignores it. Sits for a moment in misery. Finally he picks up the handset. CB
(O.S.) Got a call from Riggs, down in Galveston. Says some of the tractors you built him went haywire last night.
Just tell him to power down the controllers for a couple minutes. CB
(O.S.) I did. He wants you to come down in person anyway. Says he found something you should take a look at. 19.
stares at the wheel. Shakes his head in frustration. EXT. AIRSTRIP -- DAY
pulls his truck up to a grimy-looking hangar. Pulls a tarp off of an ancient Piper Cub. Checks it over. INT. PIPER CUB -- DAY
guides the plane along a long sliver of deserted beach. The radio crackles to life.

Bravo-two-eight, requesting permission to enter your airspace. AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL (O.S.) Permission granted. Welcome to the sovereign nation of Texas. Coop hangs up the radio. Banks the plane inland. EXT. GULF COAST -- DAY Below, a combine harvester fights its way up the dunes, trying to reach the beach, its wheels struggling for traction in the soft sand. A MAN waves up at
's plane as it circles overhead.

lands the plane on a deserted roadway. Jumps down. He intercepts one of the combines as it trundles past, trying to reach the dunes. He pops open the cabin. Inside is a mess of wires hooked into an auto-pilot not unlike the one he ripped out of the drone. He checks the fault code and resets the computer. The man jogs over to meet him. RIGGS Thanks for coming down. Half of 'em took off last night, looking for something. (points to dunes) Looks like they found it, too. I thought you were the man to see it. Riggs starts walking up the dune.

follows. Below, on the beach, a dozen more combines and other farming vehicles are lined up at the tideline, warm gulf water lapping at their metal flanks. They are circling a deep crater. 20. As they watch, an ancient autonomous SUB BEACHES itself, trying to reach the crater. EXT. CRATER'S EDGE, BEACH -- DAY

steps between the waiting machines and peers down into the crater. At the very bottom is a ROUND BLACK BALL, about a foot across -- the same object we saw punch a hole in the side of a satellite. Every few seconds, it emits a distinctive CHIRP.
checks his rad meter. A tiny reading -- non-lethal. He takes off his watch and hands it to Riggs. Then he slides down into the hole. The probe CHIRPS as
slides down on top of it. He rubs a hand across its smooth composite bulk. RIGGS (FROM ABOVE) You think it's an alien?
wipes sand off of the object, revealing the faint, familiar outline etched into the side of the probe
The stars and stripes of the old federal government.
Not exactly. EXT. CRATER'S EDGE, BEACH -- DAY Using a rope and a winch,
hauls the blackened probe out of the crater and onto the beach.
hefts it up and carries it to the back of his plane.
Space probe. Never seen one like it, though. Looks like it's been to hell and back. The probe CHIRPS as
belts it into the back. RIGGS How do you think it wound up here?
Lost, I guess. Guidance satellites would have been shot down by the Chinese twenty years ago.
looks at the probe for a second, admiring its form. 21. INT. KITCHEN,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT
is pouring a bottle of corn beer into a bubbling vat of chowder. He turns to watch
work, amused. The probe has been clamped to the kitchen table.
works at the blackened
with a BLOWTORCH.
gives up -- the torch hasn't made a scratch. The probe CHIRPS.
Well I
't know what the hell it's made of, but I can't crack it open.
Good. Clear it off the table so I can serve dinner.
and
walk in.
's got another black eye.
(CONT'D) What happened this time?
I got suspended. Paul said anyone who believed we went to the moon was an idiot. So I hit him.
Good boy. Hand me the scanner.
hands his dad a defibrillator he's modified for the purpose. He attaches the shock pads to the sides of the probe and turns on the power. Numbers flash across the screen.
hits a button on the controls and it PULSES.
(CONT'D) Here we go. Standard NASA encryption. Memory's been damaged. Just noise. Hold on. I've got something.
unplugs a monitor from his computer and plugs it into the defibrillator. After a moment, an image fills the screen
An ICE-COVERED PLANET nestled in the center of a system impossibly dense with stars.
stares, transfixed.
Where is that, dad?
I
't know.
looks at the probe. 22.
(CONT'D) Where the hell did you come from?
shrugs. Turns off the monitor.
(CONT'D) We'll take it down to Tyson's tomorrow and have it melted down. Might be some copper inside.
But what about its mission? What about the information onboard?
There's no one for it to report to. NASA is all gone. I'm sorry, son. It got home too late.
pulls his chowder off the boil and slides the pot unceremoniously onto the table. INT. DINING ROOM -- NIGHT The boys have gone to bed.
and
are alone at the table.
hands
another beer.
I heard your meeting at the school didn't go so well.
shakes his head in disgust.
Maybe it's better for everyone to forget what they did back then. Reminds us how far we've fallen.

(looks down,) When I was kid, it felt like they made something new every day. Some gadget or idea. (SMILES) Like every day was Christmas. (BEAT) But we made a lot of mistakes. Six billion people. Just try to imagine that. Every last one of them trying to have it all.
rolls the bottle of beer in his hands. 23.
(CONT'D) The truth is this world isn't that bad. In a lot of ways its better.
will be all right, whether he goes to college or not.
It doesn't bother me that he can't go. It bothers me that he doesn't care.
isn't the problem. He fits in this world just fine. You're the one who doesn't fit, Coop. You
't belong here. You were born forty years too late, or forty years too early -- I
't know. My daughter knew it, god bless her. And your kids know it, too.
drains his beer. Walks to the screen door. Stops, one hand on the frame.
(CONT'D) You were good at something and you never got a chance to do anything with it. And I'm sorry, Coop. But that's not your kids' fault.
pushes out the screen door.
looks at his beer. The probe CHIRPS. INT. BEDROOM,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT
flops down on his bed, fully clothed, exhausted. He stares up at the ceiling. This is his life. INT. BEDROOM,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT The air is filled with a PIERCING NOISE.
BOLTS upright. Stumbles out the door. INT. HALLWAY,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT
's boys are in the hallway, exhausted.
, holding a baseball bat, makes his way down the stairs.
uses the bat to open the kitchen door. INT. KITCHEN,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT
steps in,
watching from behind him. 24. The probe is clamped to the table, the chirp replaced with a DEAFENING SCREAM.

, holding his ears, moves closer to the probe. He hits it with the paddles. No result. He SMASHES it with the bat. Nothing. He HITS it AGAIN and AGAIN. Finally, the clamps break off chunks of the table and the probe slams to the ground and ROLLS toward the front door. As it rolls, it STOPS SHRIEKING.
and the others watch it roll toward the door. It stops at the wall. After a second, it begins SHRIEKING AGAIN.
grabs it and rolls it toward the front door. Once again, the movement shuts it up. EXT. PORCH,
'S HOUSE -- NIGHT
and his boys roll the probe out of the front door. It BUMPS down the front steps and comes to rest in the dirt. After a moment, the unholy RACKET starts up again.
keeps rolling it, but it doesn't seem to help.
looks up, sees the stars overhead.
Try a different direction. As they roll the probe in a circle, its SHRIEK stops, then picks up again.
zeroes in on the direction that keeps it quiet -- southwest -- and pushes it along in the dirt.
It's a fail-safe. It's going to annoy us into taking it home.
stops rolling the probe and, after a moment, it begins SHRIEKING again.
What are we going to do?
gets a rope.
We're going to get some sleep. He begins tying the rope around the probe. INT. BEDROOM,
'S HOUSE -- DAY
wakes. He's been sleeping with a pillow wrapped around his head. The SHRIEK can be heard, but it's muffled, distant. 25. INT. KITCHEN,
'S HOUSE -- DAY
heads off for school with
, still suspended, looks up at
, smiling.
What are we doing today?
You're staying here and cleaning the house.
looks crestfallen. He looks out towards the yard.
follows his stare.
(CONT'D) I told you,
. There's no one to take it back to.
But what if there is, dad? What if there's something we can salvage?
thinks it over.
scrambles to get his shoes. EXT.
'S HOUSE -- DAY The shriek is still muffled.
walks over to the well, putting in a pair of earplugs. A line is staked off, leading down into the well below.
begins hauling the line up. As the probe breaks the surface of the water, the SHRIEK returns to its normal volume.
rolls the probe out onto the ground. INT. PIPER CUB -- DAY The probe CHIRPS next to
in the backseat as

spins the plane and guns the throttle and they bounce along the dusty runway and into the air. EXT. CALIFORNIA COAST -- DAY The tiny plane follows the mountains south. EXT. SKIES OVER LOS ANGELES -- DAY

flies in low. Los Angeles looks much the same way it did in the early 20th century -- small settlements in Santa Monica and Downtown. Wildfires and earthquakes have shaken and burned what was left of the homes in between. 26. EXT. PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY, MALIBU -- DAY

puts the plane down on the old highway and taxis up to a gas station. Ahead, the Coast Highway peters out and disappears beneath rows of wild grass -- Malibu has become ranchland, once again. EXT. GAS STATION, MALIBU -- DAY An OLD MAN looks up as
steps out of the plane and checks it over.
Got any diesel? OLD MAN Plenty. Shame you can't eat it.
stretches the hose over to the plane. INT. PIPER CUB -- DAY
rests a hand lightly on the controls as he follows the coast.
gazes out the window. In the backseat, the probe is HUMMING. A light marine layer beneath them parts, revealing SANTA CRUZ ISLAND, a large, uninhabited island. As
